intro: Melampyrum japonicum, commonly known as Japanese touch-me-not, is a flowering plant native to East Asia. It belongs to the family Orobanchaceae and is characterized by its erect, branched stems and lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-orange flowers that bloom in clusters, typically from late spring to early summer. It is often found in open woodlands and grassy areas, thriving in well-drained soils. Its common name derives from the sticky glands on its stems, which can adhere to clothing or animal fur.
